questions.question: 1. Why is windowing crucial in the windowed periodogram, and how does it affect the spectral estimate?

answers.b: It increases frequency resolution by narrowing the main lobe.
answers.c: It suppresses sidelobes at the cost of main lobe widening, reducing leakage.
answers.d: It makes the estimator unbiased in the presence of colored noise.

explanations.a: Windowing reduces but does not eliminate leakage.
explanations.b: Windowing typically widens the main lobe, reducing resolution.
explanations.c: Correct — windowing suppresses sidelobes and reduces leakage, though it slightly degrades resolution.
explanations.d: Windowing doesn't affect bias due to colored noise directly.

questions.question: 2. What differentiates Welch's method from the standard Bartlett method in PSD estimation?

answers.a: Welch uses non-overlapping segments while Bartlett uses overlapping ones.
answers.b: Welch averages windowed periodograms from overlapping segments to reduce variance.
answers.c: Bartlett applies smoothing to autocorrelation before FFT, unlike Welch.
answers.d: Welch provides higher resolution by increasing DFT length per segment.

explanations.a: The reverse is true — Welch uses overlapping, Bartlett does not.
explanations.b: Correct — Welch reduces variance using overlapping and windowed segments.
explanations.d: Welch may sacrifice resolution due to shorter segments.

questions.question: 3. In the Blackman-Tukey method, what is the role of applying a window to the autocorrelation function before computing the spectrum?

answers.a: It reduces bias introduced by high-lag correlation values.
answers.b: It removes the need for zero-padding before FFT.
answers.c: It enhances frequency resolution by sharpening peaks.
answers.d: It ensures time-domain symmetry of the signal.

explanations.a: Correct — the window smooths the autocorrelation, reducing variance and limiting the effect of unreliable high-lag values.
explanations.b: Zero-padding may still be needed for interpolation but is not the purpose of windowing.
explanations.c: Windowing reduces resolution while controlling leakage.
explanations.d: Time-domain symmetry is unrelated to this step.

questions.question: 4. Which fundamental assumption allows the correlogram method to estimate the power spectral density from autocorrelation?

answers.a: The signal is periodic and band-limited.
answers.b: The signal is ergodic in correlation and wide-sense stationary.
answers.c: The noise in the signal is Gaussian white.
answers.d: The signal has a finite number of frequency components.

explanations.a: Periodicity is not required in the correlogram.
explanations.b: Correct — WSS and ergodicity allow time averages to approximate ensemble averages.
explanations.c: Noise type may influence results but isn’t a prerequisite.
explanations.d: This would describe a sinusoidal model, not the correlogram assumption.

questions.question: 5. Why does the Bartlett method result in reduced variance in spectral estimates at the expense of resolution?

answers.a: It uses fewer DFT points by design.
answers.b: It estimates fewer frequency bins by truncating the signal.
answers.c: Segmenting the signal reduces the effective DFT length, lowering resolution.
answers.d: It applies a high-pass filter to the signal before segmentation.

explanations.a: DFT points can remain the same — it's the segment length that matters.
explanations.b: Bartlett doesn’t truncate the signal — it divides it.
explanations.c: Correct — shorter segments mean coarser frequency resolution.
explanations.d: High-pass filtering is unrelated to Bartlett’s averaging mechanism.

questions.question: 6. Suppose you apply Welch’s method to a signal with significant low-frequency content. What kind of window would help reduce leakage while preserving that low-frequency information?

answers.c: A Blackman window with minimal side lobes.
answers.d: A Kaiser window with large β value.

explanations.a: Rectangular windows have high side lobes and increase leakage.
explanations.b: Hamming and Hann provide a good balance for general spectral estimation.
explanations.c: Correct — Blackman is ideal for minimizing leakage, though it further reduces resolution.
explanations.d: Kaiser with large β suppresses leakage but may be too aggressive for low-frequency preservation.

questions.question: 7. Which of the following is a primary limitation of the correlogram method for PSD estimation?

answers.c: It has inherently low frequency resolution due to non-segmented averaging.
answers.d: It introduces spectral nulls due to autocorrelation bias.

explanations.a: True for all WSS-based estimators, but not unique to correlogram.
explanations.b: Bias depends on lag estimation, not specific overestimation.
explanations.c: Correct — unlike segment-based methods, resolution is limited by single long-time autocorrelation.
explanations.d: Bias introduces distortion, but not spectral nulls specifically.

questions.question: 8. What effect does overlapping segments have in Welch's method compared to Bartlett's method?

answers.a: It reduces resolution but improves detection of weak tones.
answers.b: It increases spectral leakage due to redundant data.
answers.c: It improves variance reduction without further resolution loss.
answers.d: It causes windowing artifacts to accumulate.

explanations.a: Overlap doesn't reduce resolution directly — segment length does.
explanations.c: Correct — overlapping improves variance reduction by increasing the number of independent estimates.
explanations.d: Artifacts are minimized due to proper windowing.

questions.question: 9. How does the Blackman-Tukey method trade off between resolution and variance?

answers.a: By using zero-padding to interpolate the spectrum.
answers.b: By truncating the autocorrelation and applying a smoothing window.
answers.c: By increasing overlap between segments for averaging.
answers.d: By averaging the magnitude spectrum instead of the power spectrum.

explanations.a: Zero-padding helps with visual resolution, but not the variance-resolution tradeoff.
explanations.b: Correct — this combination reduces variance at the cost of frequency resolution.
explanations.d: Averaging magnitudes is not part of Blackman-Tukey.

questions.question: 10. Which method provides the most consistent estimate (in the statistical sense) of the true PSD as the number of data samples increases?

explanations.a: The periodogram is inconsistent — its variance does not decrease with more data.
explanations.b: Correct — Bartlett produces consistent estimates by averaging uncorrelated segments.
explanations.c: Depends on assumptions; can be biased and inconsistent depending on window choice.
explanations.d: Welch is more consistent than periodogram but not strictly consistent in all cases.
